text:
We have Apache 2.0.52 with OpenSSL running on Windows 2000 server acting as
reverse proxy to enable HTTPS for an HTTP client. The server side is a Cisco
11500 switch with SSL module.

The Cisco switch is configured to perform client authentication.

In our load test with 44 HTTP clients, usually between 20~40 minutes apache will
have issues. The issue will manifest itself in several different ways:

1. When cisco switch sends its certificate and client certificate request,
apache sends back Fatal Bad Certificate error
2. Same situation, apache sends back TLS record with missing certificate (zero
length) and missing Certificate Verify record.

Both issues are usually accompanied with an "Access Violation" pop-up window.
creator: xiaoqing.zhu@convergys.com

text:
Created attachment 14562
Apache configuration 

The virtual host in question is vwachvxmlssl.
creator: xiaoqing.zhu@convergys.com

text: Can you reproduce this with 2.0.53?  Can you get a backtrace when it crashes?
creator: jorton@redhat.com

text:
Created attachment 14595
trace of a 'good' and a 'bad' SSL handshake
creator: xiaoqing.zhu@convergys.com

text:
Have not yet tried with 2.0.53. Backtrace of a 'good' handshake versus the first
'bad' handshake posted.
creator: xiaoqing.zhu@convergys.com

text:
By an "Access Violation" popup do you mean that Apache has crashed?  If so, can
you get a stack back trace from the crash?

From the protocol trace it looks simply like the Cisco server is sending a
handshake failure; can you get anything further from the server logs about why?
 That itself isn't necessarily a mod_ssl bug.

1 9  0.0057 (0.0002)  S>CV3.1(2)  Alert
    level           fatal
    value           handshake_failure
creator: jorton@redhat.com
wrowe@apache.org
text:
No further response from submittor, closing.

Note that http://httpd.apache.org/dev/debugging.html can be used as a guide
for obtaining the symbols and capturing a backtrace with dr watson, which we
would need in order to reopen the incident, if the problem still occurs.
